elements.content: The assembly of 1,4-bis­(pyrid-4-yl)­benzene (bpb) and Fe­(NCS)2 affords three supramolecular isomeric frameworks formulated as [Fe­(bpb)2(NCS)2]·X (X = 3EtOH for 1, 2.5H2O for 2, and 0 for 3, respectively). Crystallographic studies reveal that 1 belongs to the monoclinic space group C2/c and crystallizes into a threefold self-interpenetrated 3D 65·8 CdSO4-type framework, whereas 2 crystallizes in the monoclinic space group P2/c and features a 2D 44 square-grid network. The immersion of red crystals of 1 into a methanol/ethanol (1:3) solvent led to the formation of yellow crystals of 3, showing structural transformation via crystal disassembly and reassembly process. 3 crystallizes in the triclinic space group P1̅ and is a 2D 44 rhombus-grid network, but showing nonporous feature (compared with 2) because of more compact network stacking. The most interesting feature is that crystals of 3 are not able to be synthesized by the direct reaction of Fe­(NCS)2 with ligand bpb. We suppose that this structural isomerization is a solvent-mediated rearrangement of coordination bonds from a kinetically favored isomer (1) to the thermodynamically stable form (3) of the system. It is generally believed that the framework of higher dimensionality is a more stable phase than that of lower dimensionality. While conversions between supramolecular isomers from 1D to 2D, 1D to 3D, and 2D to 3D have been observed, examples showing 3D to 2D or 3D to 1D isomerization are rarely reported. The structural transformation herein represents a rather scarce case from higher dimensional framework (3D) to lower one (2D).
elements.clean_text: The assembly of 1,4-bis(pyrid-4-yl)benzene (bpb) and Fe(NCS)2 affords three supramolecular isomeric frameworks formulated as [Fe(bpb)2(NCS)2]⋅X (X = 3EtOH for 1, 2.5H2O for 2, and 0 for 3, respectively). Crystallographic studies reveal that 1 belongs to the monoclinic space group C2/c and crystallizes into a threefold self-interpenetrated 3D 65⋅8 CdSO4-type framework, whereas 2 crystallizes in the monoclinic space group P2/c and features a 2D 44 square-grid network. The immersion of red crystals of 1 into a methanol/ethanol (1:3) solvent led to the formation of yellow crystals of 3, showing structural transformation via crystal disassembly and reassembly process. 3 crystallizes in the triclinic space group P1̅ and is a 2D 44 rhombus-grid network, but showing nonporous feature (compared with 2) because of more compact network stacking. The most interesting feature is that crystals of 3 are not able to be synthesized by the direct reaction of Fe(NCS)2 with ligand bpb. We suppose that this structural isomerization is a solvent-mediated rearrangement of coordination bonds from a kinetically favored isomer (1) to the thermodynamically stable form (3) of the system. It is generally believed that the framework of higher dimensionality is a more stable phase than that of lower dimensionality. While conversions between supramolecular isomers from 1D to 2D, 1D to 3D, and 2D to 3D have been observed, examples showing 3D to 2D or 3D to 1D isomerization are rarely reported. The structural transformation herein represents a rather scarce case from higher dimensional framework (3D) to lower one (2D).

elements.content: The assembly of 1,4-bis­(pyrid-4-yl)­benzene (bpb) and Fe­(NCS)2 affords three supramolecular isomeric frameworks featuring different topological structures. Solvent-mediated isomerization from a 3D 65·8 framework to the isomeric 2D 44 rhombus-grid network is observed.
elements.clean_text: The assembly of 1,4-bis(pyrid-4-yl)benzene (bpb) and Fe(NCS)2 affords three supramolecular isomeric frameworks featuring different topological structures. Solvent-mediated isomerization from a 3D 65⋅8 framework to the isomeric 2D 44 rhombus-grid network is observed.

elements.content: Supramolecular isomerism has been widely encountered and studied in the field of crystal engineering. The same reactants may afford supramolecular isomers with different topologic structures in which the coordination networks have the same chemical composition. Supramolecular isomers may show significant variations in chemical and physical properties and thus open a good opportunity for developing novel functional materials. Interconversion between supramolecular isomers in a coordination polymeric system may occur at specific conditions, which is common to the polymorphic transformations in molecular systems. Up to now, only a few examples of transformation from one isomer to another in the solid state are reported due to the high conversion barriers between different isomers in coordination polymeric systems, which are formed by strong coordination bonds. However, disassembly of the building blocks of coordination polymeric systems in solution may reduce the conversion barriers and help to transform from one isomer to another by reassembly. This kind of solvent-mediated isomerization is actually a thermodynamically controlled recrystallization process following the Ostwald’s Rule of Stages.
elements.clean_text: Supramolecular isomerism has been widely encountered and studied in the field of crystal engineering. The same reactants may afford supramolecular isomers with different topologic structures in which the coordination networks have the same chemical composition. Supramolecular isomers may show significant variations in chemical and physical properties and thus open a good opportunity for developing novel functional materials. Interconversion between supramolecular isomers in a coordination polymeric system may occur at specific conditions, which is common to the polymorphic transformations in molecular systems. Up to now, only a few examples of transformation from one isomer to another in the solid state are reported due to the high conversion barriers between different isomers in coordination polymeric systems, which are formed by strong coordination bonds. However, disassembly of the building blocks of coordination polymeric systems in solution may reduce the conversion barriers and help to transform from one isomer to another by reassembly. This kind of solvent-mediated isomerization is actually a thermodynamically controlled recrystallization process following the Ostwald's Rule of Stages.

elements.content: The spin-crossover (SCO) phenomenon relates to the octahedral d4–d7 transition metal complexes with electronic configurations switchable between high-spin (HS) and low-spin (LS) states under external stimuli, e.g., temperature, magnetic field, pressure, or light irradiation. In particular, the judicious combination of 4,4′-bipyridine type rigid linear “spacers” and square planar Fe­(NCS)2 “nodes” has afforded noteworthy thermal- and light-induced SCO-active coordination frameworks showing (4,4)-connected topologic structures. Coordination networks based solely upon grid-planar nodes are able to show several different topologies and therefore supramolecular isomers, such as 2D 44 grid, 3D 65·8 CdSO4 and 64·82 NbO. Herein, we report the syntheses and structures of three supramolecular isomeric coordination polymers formulated as [Fe­(bpb)2(NCS)2]·X [X = 3EtOH for 1, 2.5H2O for 2, and 0 for 3, respectively; bpb = 1,4-bis­(pyrid-4-yl)­benzene (Scheme )], and the solvent-mediated isomerization from 3D 65·8 CdSO4-type 1 to 2D 44 rhombus-grid 3 featuring a color change from red (1) to yellow (3), which suggests that the spin states of the FeII centers might change concomitantly. Structural transformation from a metastable 3D network to a stable 2D isomeric phase is unusual in the field of coordination polymers. The framework of higher dimensionality is generally believed to be more stable than that of lower dimensionality. While conversions between supramolecular isomers from 1D to 2D, 1D to 3D, and 2D to 3D have been observed, examples showing 3D to 2D or 3D to 1D isomerization are rarely reported.
elements.clean_text: The spin-crossover (SCO) phenomenon relates to the octahedral d4-d7 transition metal complexes with electronic configurations switchable between high-spin (HS) and low-spin (LS) states under external stimuli, e.g., temperature, magnetic field, pressure, or light irradiation. In particular, the judicious combination of 4,4'-bipyridine type rigid linear "spacers" and square planar Fe(NCS)2 "nodes" has afforded noteworthy thermal- and light-induced SCO-active coordination frameworks showing (4,4)-connected topologic structures. Coordination networks based solely upon grid-planar nodes are able to show several different topologies and therefore supramolecular isomers, such as 2D 44 grid, 3D 65⋅8 CdSO4  and 64⋅82 NbO. Herein, we report the syntheses and structures of three supramolecular isomeric coordination polymers formulated as [Fe(bpb)2(NCS)2]⋅X [X = 3EtOH for 1, 2.5H2O for 2, and 0 for 3, respectively; bpb = 1,4-bis(pyrid-4-yl)benzene (Scheme )], and the solvent-mediated isomerization from 3D 65⋅8 CdSO4-type 1 to 2D 44 rhombus-grid 3 featuring a color change from red (1) to yellow (3), which suggests that the spin states of the FeII centers might change concomitantly. Structural transformation from a metastable 3D network to a stable 2D isomeric phase is unusual in the field of coordination polymers. The framework of higher dimensionality is generally believed to be more stable than that of lower dimensionality. While conversions between supramolecular isomers from 1D to 2D, 1D to 3D, and 2D to 3D have been observed, examples showing 3D to 2D or 3D to 1D isomerization are rarely reported.

elements.content:
<fig fig-type="scheme" id="sch1" orientation="portrait" position="float">
<label>1</label>
<caption>
<title>Square-Planar Node of [Fe­(bpb)<sub>2</sub>(NCS)<sub>2</sub>]</title>
</caption>
<graphic id="gr1" orientation="portrait" position="float" xlink:href="cg-2014-011506_0004.tif"></graphic>
</fig>

The reaction of Fe­(NCS)2 and bpb in a methanol/ethanol solution (v/v = 1:3) afforded two kinds of crystals with distinct differences in color and size, i.e., large red block crystals of 1 and small yellow crystals of 2, respectively. When crystals of 1 were immersed in a methanol/ethanol (v/v = 1:3) solution, the red crystals (1) dissolved slowly, accompanying with simultaneous crystallization of new crystalsyellow 3and finally the dissolution–crystallization process completed in 5 days, as shown in Figure . It is reasonable to hypothesize that 3 represents the lowest free-energy state and is the most stable form in solution, but suffers higher activation energy for nucleation. As a result, no crystal of 3 was obtained by the direct reaction of Fe­(NCS)2 and ligand bpb. Instead, 1 should have the lowest energy barrier for nucleation, thus nucleated quickly and crystallized out at a faster rate. Solvent-mediated isomerization is thus accessible by crystal disassembly of 1 and assembly of 3. Crystals of 2 co-crystallized with 1 in a one-pot reaction, but had a much lower productivity, which is probably due to the higher energy barrier for nucleation. No transformation from 2 to 3 was observed. The purities of 1 and 3 are confirmed by PXRD. The PXRD pattern of 2, however, is not matched with the calculated results from single-crystal diffraction data, which is probably due to the structural change caused by desolvation (see ).

When crystals of 1 were immersed in a methanol/ethanol (v/v = 1:3) solution, the red crystals (1) dissolved slowly, accompanying with simultaneous crystallization of new crystalsyellow 3and finally the dissolution-crystallization process completed in 5 days, as shown in Figure . It is reasonable to hypothesize that 3 represents the lowest free-energy state and is the most stable form in solution, but suffers higher activation energy for nucleation. As a result, no crystal of 3 was obtained by the direct reaction of Fe(NCS)2 and ligand bpb. Instead, 1 should have the lowest energy barrier for nucleation, thus nucleated quickly and crystallized out at a faster rate. Solvent-mediated isomerization is thus accessible by crystal disassembly of 1 and assembly of 3. Crystals of 2 co-crystallized with 1 in a one-pot reaction, but had a much lower productivity, which is probably due to the higher energy barrier for nucleation. No transformation from 2 to 3 was observed. The purities of 1 and 3 are confirmed by PXRD. The PXRD pattern of 2, however, is not matched with the calculated results from single-crystal diffraction data, which is probably due to the structural change caused by desolvation (see ).

elements.content: Optical images of the solvent-mediated isomerization from 1 (red) to 3 (yellow). (a) 1 min; (b) 12 h; (c) 2 days; (d) 5 days.
elements.clean_text: 1  Optical images of the solvent-mediated isomerization from 1 (red) to 3 (yellow). (a) 1 min; (b) 12 h; (c) 2 days; (d) 5 days.

elements.content: Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analyses indicate that the framework structures of complexes 1, 2, and 3 are supramolecular isomers formulated as [Fe­(bpb)2(NCS)2]. Octahedral geometries on the FeII centers are found in the three crystal structures, in which the FeII ion is bound to two trans NCS– anions and four bpb ligands, as shown in Scheme . The FeII center is in a grid-planar arrangement constituting the basic building unit for the 2D and 3D isomeric networks. At 100 K, the Fe–Npyridine bond lengths, in the range of 2.267(3)–2.235(6) Å for 2 and 2.226(2)–2.2878(18) Å for 3 are slightly larger than the Fe–NNCS – bond lengths of 2.090(4) and 2.0940(18) Å for 2 and 3, indicating the high-spin state of FeII ions in 2 and 3. For 1, the Fe–N distances are in range of 2.203(3)–2.090(4) Å with an average value of 2.167 Å at 100 K, which is slightly shorter than those of 2 and 3 (average Fe–N bond lengths of 2.202 Å for both complexes, Table S2–4 in ). The relatively shorter Fe–N bond lengths in 1 indicate that the FeII ions in 1 have undergone spin crossover at 100 K, in agreement with the magnetic data (see below).
elements.clean_text: Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analyses indicate that the framework structures of complexes 1, 2, and 3 are supramolecular isomers formulated as [Fe(bpb)2(NCS)2]. Octahedral geometries on the FeII centers are found in the three crystal structures, in which the FeII ion is bound to two trans NCS- anions and four bpb ligands, as shown in Scheme . The FeII center is in a grid-planar arrangement constituting the basic building unit for the 2D and 3D isomeric networks. At 100 K, the Fe-Npyridine bond lengths, in the range of 2.267(3)-2.235(6) Å for 2 and 2.226(2)-2.2878(18) Å for 3 are slightly larger than the Fe-NNCS - bond lengths of 2.090(4) and 2.0940(18) Å for 2 and 3, indicating the high-spin state of FeII ions in 2 and 3. For 1, the Fe-N distances are in range of 2.203(3)-2.090(4) Å with an average value of 2.167 Å at 100 K, which is slightly shorter than those of 2 and 3 (average Fe-N bond lengths of 2.202 Å for both complexes, Table S2-4 in ). The relatively shorter Fe-N bond lengths in 1 indicate that the FeII ions in 1 have undergone spin crossover at 100 K, in agreement with the magnetic data (see below).

elements.content: The three-dimensional structure of 1 can be assigned to the 3D 65·8 CdSO4 framework, which possesses a large space inside available for other identical networks to reside forming a threefold interpenetrated structure with 1D channels along the c axis (Figure a,b, Figure S4 in ). The 1D channels are occupied by ethanol molecules, as revealed by elemental and thermogravimetric analyses (see ). The Fe–Fe distances through the bpb linkers are 15.768(2) Å and 15.825(3) Å, while the closest internetwork Fe–Fe separation is 10.131(2) Å. The two pyridine groups of the bpb ligand in 1 could rotate and present various conformations, implying that the threefold interpenetration does not form the most dense structure in this system.
elements.clean_text: The three-dimensional structure of 1 can be assigned to the 3D 65⋅8 CdSO4 framework, which possesses a large space inside available for other identical networks to reside forming a threefold interpenetrated structure with 1D channels along the c axis (Figure a,b, Figure S4 in ). The 1D channels are occupied by ethanol molecules, as revealed by elemental and thermogravimetric analyses (see ). The Fe-Fe distances through the bpb linkers are 15.768(2) Å and 15.825(3) Å, while the closest internetwork Fe-Fe separation is 10.131(2) Å. The two pyridine groups of the bpb ligand in 1 could rotate and present various conformations, implying that the threefold interpenetration does not form the most dense structure in this system.

elements.content: Complex 2 is a 2D 44 square-grid planar network with square dimension of 15.888 Å × 15.928 Å. Adjacent layers are organized alternately in an ABAB manner in the bc plane, forming 1D channels (Figure c,d, Figure S5 in ) parallel to the a axis for solvent molecules (two and half water molecules per FeII ion) to reside. In such stacking style, only the benzyl group of ligand bpb that is perpendicular to the b axis rotate freely.
elements.clean_text: Complex 2 is a 2D 44 square-grid planar network with square dimension of 15.888 Å × 15.928 Å. Adjacent layers are organized alternately in an ABAB manner in the bc plane, forming 1D channels (Figure c,d, Figure S5 in ) parallel to the a axis for solvent molecules (two and half water molecules per FeII ion) to reside. In such stacking style, only the benzyl group of ligand bpb that is perpendicular to the b axis rotate freely.

elements.content: The structure of 3 is also a 2D 44 network (Figure e,f), but its rhombic grid (15.317 Å × 15.711 Å) is different in shape from the planar layer of 2. The consecutive layers in 3 are arranged in the offset rather than face-to-face fashion, leading to a nonporous 3D close-packing structure (Figure S6 in ). None of the pyridine or benzyl group of ligand bpb is found to rotate or disorder. By comparing the rotation of ligand bpb in the three structures, we can conclude that structural stability or density follows the order of 3 (no rotation) > 2 (one benzyl group rotation) > 1 (two pyridine groups rotation).
elements.clean_text: The structure of 3 is also a 2D 44 network (Figure e,f), but its rhombic grid (15.317 Å × 15.711 Å) is different in shape from the planar layer of 2. The consecutive layers in 3 are arranged in the offset rather than face-to-face fashion, leading to a nonporous 3D close-packing structure (Figure S6 in ). None of the pyridine or benzyl group of ligand bpb is found to rotate or disorder. By comparing the rotation of ligand bpb in the three structures, we can conclude that structural stability or density follows the order of 3 (no rotation) > 2 (one benzyl group rotation) > 1 (two pyridine groups rotation).

elements.content: During the transformation from 1 to its supramolecular isomer 3, the 3D 65·8 CdSO4 structure disassembles with the concomitant reassembly of the 2D 44 layer. The crystal packing features transforms from an open porous structure (1) to a more dense structure (3). The most appealing change during the transformation is reflected in their totally different colors at room temperature, that is, red for 1 and yellow for 3, respectively, indicating that the spin states of the FeII centers at room temperature might have changed.
elements.clean_text: During the transformation from 1 to its supramolecular isomer 3, the 3D 65⋅8 CdSO4 structure disassembles with the concomitant reassembly of the 2D 44 layer. The crystal packing features transforms from an open porous structure (1) to a more dense structure (3). The most appealing change during the transformation is reflected in their totally different colors at room temperature, that is, red for 1 and yellow for 3, respectively, indicating that the spin states of the FeII centers at room temperature might have changed.

elements.content: 3D 65·8 CdSO4 framework (a) and topologic threefold interpenetrated structure (b) of 1, the 2D square-grid layer (c) and ABAB stacking pattern (d) of 2, and the 2D rhombus-grid layer (e) and offset arrangement of layers (f) of 3. The NCS– ions on FeII centers, lattice solvent molecules and hydrogen atoms are omitted for clarity.
elements.clean_text: 2  3D 65⋅8 CdSO4 framework (a) and topologic threefold interpenetrated structure (b) of 1, the 2D square-grid layer (c) and ABAB stacking pattern (d) of 2, and the 2D rhombus-grid layer (e) and offset arrangement of layers (f) of 3. The NCS- ions on FeII centers, lattice solvent molecules and hydrogen atoms are omitted for clarity.

elements.content: The magnetic susceptibilities of 1, 2, and 3 were measured using a SQUID magnetometer under magnetic field of 0.5 T. The results are shown in Figure in the form of χM T versus T plots, where χM is molar magnetic susceptibility and T is temperature. For 2 and 3, the χM T values at 300 K are 3.24 and 3.48 cm3 K mol–1, respectively, being typical values for an HS FeII ion in octahedral coordination geometry. The χM T values of 2 and 3 remain essentially constant upon cooling, then decrease below 25 K possibly due to the zero-field splitting of HS FeII ions. These magnetic behaviors indicate that 2 and 3 do not undergo spin crossover. The χM T value of 1 is 2.93 cm3 K mol–1 at 300 K, lower than those of 2 and 3 and the normal value of an HS FeII ion (3.0–3.5 cm3 K mol–1), which decreases upon cooling and indicates that the FeII ions in 1 have undergone spin crossover at room temperature. A value of 2.56 cm3 K mol–1 is reached at 160 K and remains constant until a sudden decrease occurs below 25 K. This profile shows that a thermally induced incomplete spin crossover of 1 is thus inferred.
elements.clean_text: The magnetic susceptibilities of 1, 2, and 3 were measured using a SQUID magnetometer under magnetic field of 0.5 T. The results are shown in Figure  in the form of χM T versus T plots, where χM is molar magnetic susceptibility and T is temperature. For 2 and 3, the χM T values at 300 K are 3.24 and 3.48 cm3 K mol-1, respectively, being typical values for an HS FeII ion in octahedral coordination geometry. The χM T values of 2 and 3 remain essentially constant upon cooling, then decrease below 25 K possibly due to the zero-field splitting of HS FeII ions. These magnetic behaviors indicate that 2 and 3 do not undergo spin crossover. The χM T value of 1 is 2.93 cm3 K mol-1 at 300 K, lower than those of 2 and 3 and the normal value of an HS FeII ion (3.0-3.5 cm3 K mol-1), which decreases upon cooling and indicates that the FeII ions in 1 have undergone spin crossover at room temperature. A value of 2.56 cm3 K mol-1 is reached at 160 K and remains constant until a sudden decrease occurs below 25 K. This profile shows that a thermally induced incomplete spin crossover of 1 is thus inferred.

elements.content: χM T versus T plots for complexes 1, 2, and 3.
elements.clean_text: 3  χM T versus T plots for complexes 1, 2, and 3.

elements.content: In summary, we have successfully obtained three FeII supramolecular isomeric coordination polymers, 3D CdSO4-type framework (1) and two 2D 44 networks (2 and 3) with square building units, respectively, and realized a solvent-mediated isomerization from 1 to 3 associated with dramatic color change from red (1) to yellow (3). The transformation is related to the disassembly and reassembly of crystals in solution. 1 is kinetically favored and would crystallize out first in a supersaturated solution, while 3 has a lower free energy and is thermodynamically stable form in solution, solvent-mediated isomerization is thus accessible along with the gradual dissolution of 1 and concomitant crystallization of 3.
elements.clean_text: In summary, we have successfully obtained three FeII supramolecular isomeric coordination polymers, 3D CdSO4-type framework (1) and two 2D 44 networks (2 and 3) with square building units, respectively, and realized a solvent-mediated isomerization from 1 to 3 associated with dramatic color change from red (1) to yellow (3). The transformation is related to the disassembly and reassembly of crystals in solution. 1 is kinetically favored and would crystallize out first in a supersaturated solution, while 3 has a lower free energy and is thermodynamically stable form in solution, solvent-mediated isomerization is thus accessible along with the gradual dissolution of 1 and concomitant crystallization of 3.

The authors declare no competing financial interest.

cln_elements.content:
Complex 2 is a 2D 44 square-grid planar network with square dimension of 15.888 Å × 15.928 Å. Adjacent layers are organized alternately in an ABAB manner in the bc plane, forming 1D channels (Figure c,d, Figure S5 in ) parallel to the a axis for solvent molecules (two and half water molecules per FeII ion) to reside. In such stacking style, only the benzyl group of ligand bpb that is perpendicular to the b axis rotate freely.

Crystal data for complex 3: C34H24FeN6S2, M r = 636.56 g mol–1, triclinic, P1̅, Z = 1, a = 7.7312(4) Å, b = 9.0974(4) Å, c = 11.4447(6) Å, α = 99.140(4)°, β = 99.140(4)°, γ = 104.366(5) °, V = 734.33(7) Å3, D c = 1.439 g cm–3, μ(Mo Kα) = 0.691 mm–1; 4921 data measured, 2883 unique (R int = 0.0221), 277 parameters, R 1 = 0.0398 (2484 with I > 2σ(I)), wR 2 = 0.1365(all data), S = 0.998.
cln_elements.clean_text:
Complex 2 is a 2D 44 square-grid planar network with square dimension of 15.888 Å × 15.928 Å. Adjacent layers are organized alternately in an ABAB manner in the bc plane, forming 1D channels (Figure c,d, Figure S5 in ) parallel to the a axis for solvent molecules (two and half water molecules per FeII ion) to reside. In such stacking style, only the benzyl group of ligand bpb that is perpendicular to the b axis rotate freely.

Crystal data in CIF format and experimental details, figures, TGA, PXRD and IR spectra. This material is available free of charge via the Internet at http://pubs.acs.org.

The authors declare no competing financial interest.

References
